page.title: 14THE RIVERSIDE WALK, PRUDHOE
page.content: The date is the 7/5/85, a bright blue sky and a lovely day for a walk along the banks of the Tyne. Starting at the newly built centre which gives information about the animals you may see on the 2_3 mile walk, millions of flowers are seen growing in clumps along the grass. Gay, waving flowers from gorse bushes mingle with the gishing of the river, which holds brown trout, eels, dace and salmon, plus many more which a fisherman enjoys catching on a peaceful day. On the banks of the Tyne lie pinkkk and white pebbles all different shades and shapes. Much of the grassland is grazed by cattle, and to protect new areas from stock, temporary fencing has been necessary until the trees become established.
